Besides exposing the players to interesting and fascinating facts about ancient Egyptian culture, the Mummy's Message classroom simulation game allows each of the players to experience the thrills, frustrations, and horrible dangers as they become archeologists traveling through the interior of a pyramid. The 50 Problem Cards and the possible impact that facing these dangers have on the expeditionary teams’ successful progress through the pyramid, took three years of research alone. As the players will discover, archeological expeditions into pyramids encountered many physical and emotional challenges as the result of the sadistic mind of the pyramid builder, who incorporated deadly traps in order to frustrate and confuse grave robbers.

Three groups are created, each with two competing archeological teams (approximately five players per team). The teams progress through the pyramid by correctly answering Question Cards, selecting a Passage Progress Card and collecting Hieroglyphic Cards, each with a hieroglyphic symbol and the translation of that symbol. Although most of the symbols were created to resemble actual hieroglyphics, the simulated experiences encountered as the players collect, piece together, and correctly translate a real message from a hieroglyphic tablet, is authentic.

The goal of the two competing archeological teams is to travel to each of the three chambers; the Pharaoh’s Burial Chamber, the Queen’s Burial Chamber and the Great Hall. As each chamber is entered, a piece or several pieces of a Hieroglyphic Tablet is/are discovered. Using the Hieroglyphic Cards accumulated, the team that can correctly piece together and translate the Mummy's Message wins the simulation game.

34328.name: The Search for the Lost Dutchman′s Gold Mine
34328.description:
As described by Dr. Scott Simmerman, the publisher:

Lost Dutchman is normally played with 5 / 6 people on a team, with 3 to a 100+ teams. It scales up really well for large group events of 150 or more people.

It is designed for large team building and strategic planning events as well as for small group classroom training situations.

The Design:

The challenge is to collaborate, rather than to compete, and to share resources and do sufficient planning to optimize overall results. The reality is that teams often choose to compete, thus making choices that sub-optimize results.

Components include a colorful map, a Grub Stake of resource cards, planning tools, job aids and other information about the game and the goals. Putting on cowboy hats and colorful bandannas, the group settles in to briefly hear the history of the Lost Dutchman's Mine and to learn the mechanics of the challenge.

The team is given 20 days of 2 minutes each to manage their journey to the mine and back home to Apache Junction. They can choose from 3 paths with different risks, planning for weather changes and focusing on the optimal use of resources. They are given the opportunity to gain additional information valuable to their journey's success but must decide if they are willing to delay their start by one or two days in order to obtain this information. After being given the introductory information, the team has 15 minutes to plan. They must work together to make decisions about tactics, resource management, direction and risk.

The 20 days of play (roughly 35 minutes) begin and are marked by lots of lively interaction among players and teams in the spirit of collaboration and competition. During this time, they'll discover the impact of their early decisions on their results. They can choose to get advice or collaborate with others.

The goal is to get to the mine, mine as much gold as WE can, and return to Apache Junction. All teams are successful, but the ones that plan and collaborate will optimize their results. Debriefing can focus on collaboration, planning, leadership, motivation, optimization of organizational performance results and many other themes.

34329.description:
Teploie, "Las colinas de hierro" ("The iron heights") is a wargame included in Alea Magazine number 7 (March-April 1990).

The game portrays the battle for the Teploie village and heights during the July 1943 Kursk offensive. The German units are part of Army Group Center. One hex represents 1 km.
Game includes a small map (42x29 cm), one countersheet with 160 counters, and eight pages of rules. The CRT and Terrain Effects Chart are printed on the back of the map, so they should be photocopied. Next Alea (number 8, May-June 1990) includes errata, additions and clarifications for the game.
34329.name: Teploie

34330.description:
In this game, Conni and her friends go for the first time to the Kindergarten.
Everyone has to hang his or her coat on a special coathanger, that is marked with a special symbol.

All players try to find the 8 images that make up the coathangers in the classroom by selecting a card and flipping it.
If the image revealed is the same as one of the missing images on that player's card, then he or she can take the card and place it on the card.
The first player to find all 8 images for his card wins the game.
34330.name: Conni im Kindergarten

34331.name: Ram
34331.description:
The object of the game is to build and complete herds of sheep, thus gaining points for you partnership (or individuals if playing so). The point values are determined by the composition of the herds. While points are earned for all herds, completed herds earn more points than non-completed herds.
There are also rules for two players.

34332.name: Frontear: The New Worlde
34332.description:
From the Website:

The World of Valon, home to Flintloque and Slaughterloo, goes to Amerka the New Worlde.

The Frontear book contains a full background (more than sixty pages) to the New Worlde, covering the discovery of Amerka to the Pilgrimes and then the Amerkan Rebellion before moving onto the War of Eighteen Bells and then the titantic clash of the Civile Warre and the Wylde West. The book also contains Full Skirmish Rules covering all these periods, an Amerkan Weapons section, three starter scenarios (for supplied miniatures) tables and all needed statistics, counters and more!

Based on the same D10 engine as Flintloque the Skirmish, this game will be instantly 'user friendly' to all who have play Flintloque and will take only one game to learn for those who have not.

Also included are, dice and twelve painted metal 28mm miniatures with textured metal round bases. Wild Bill Hickorc, Pisol Petro, Deputy Dawg, Vickars and the Dark Elf bandit gang led by disgraced Elf Souffern Confederate Officer Paule La'Regreet.

34333.name: Alice in Wonderland: A Card Game
34333.description:
This game is based on Alice in Wonderland, containing the following cards:

3 Caterpillar, 4 Duchess, 4 White Rabbit, 4 Executioner, 4 Gardener, 5 Knave of Hearts, 4 Cheshire cat, 5 Alice, 4 Queen of Hearts, 6 Mad Hatter, 4 King of Hearts, and 5 March Hares

34334.description:
With Napoleon’s escape from exile and return to France, his Grande Armée is once again on the march. Can the Anglo-Allied forces under Wellington and the Prussian army under Blücher stop him?

Waterloo 20 is the first in a series of games featuring low unit density on the map (20 pieces or less per side) and medium complexity.

Veteran designer Joseph Miranda has reduced the complexity and focused the scope of Napoleonic campaigns with his Napoleonic 20 game system. This system provides for operational level maneuvers and also has random event cards and night game turns to provide some of the “friction of war” that affected both sides greatly during the campaign.

Morale plays an important role on both sides as players can ‘spend’ some to force march their pieces, help rally stragglers, or urge their troops on as they advance in battle.

Consists of 9 pages of rules (8 for standard rules, one for game-specific rules), 40 die-cut 5/8" counters, an 11" x 17" map and 12 random event cards.
34334.name: Waterloo 20
boardgamepodcastepisode: Point 2 Point 38: Waterloo 20

34335.name: Bomb Tokyo!
34335.description:
This is a unique combination of dexterity and wargame. You drop clay 'bombs' through holes in the provided airplanes and hope they stick to the target locations on the board. Earn points for completing the bombing missions during World War II.

The game was shipped in a cardboard tube and has a colorful illustrated map.

34336.name: Wyntre Golf
34336.description: This golf game comes in a blue box. There is a wheel and a green table in the center of the board and several tracks go up the side of the table, around the wheel, and then back down the other side of the table. Graphics of golfers surround the functional parts of the board.

34337.name: Bowling: A Board Game
34337.description: Perhaps the earliest bowling boardgame, this game's box features a woman bowling while wearing a dress. The board is a grid of 48 squares with various numbers of pins, spares, strikes or fouls listed.

34338.name: The Green Acres Game
34338.description: This is a Green Acres themed roll-and-move game, with the track going around the outside of the board like Monopoly. The object of the game is to be the first player to buy enough equipment to start running your farm.

34339.name: Serial Killer Trivia Game
34339.description: The Serial Killer Trivia Game features Ted Bundy, the Green River Killer Gary Ridgway and Spokane's serial killer Robert Yates. The game places the players in the middle of some of the most notorious cases of our time with a roll of a dice.

34341.name: Gambit
34341.description: Gambit is a trick taking game where points are awarded not only for the tricks taken, but also for the card that wins the trick.

boardgamehonor: 2008 Boardgames Australia Awards Best Australian Game Nominee
34342.name: Sorts
34342.description:
Sorts is a party game based on ordering items in lists (e.g. celebrities by year of birth). A card of colour-coded list items is drawn, and the players slot like coloured tiles into position in a plastic holder. The reverse of the list card shows the correct order.

Example: Sort these animals by the usual number of adult teeth they have:

rabbit
gopher
elephant
dog
bottlenose dolphin




If you said: bottlenose dolphin (76-98), dog (42), rabbit (28), elephant (24), gopher (20)...then you have what it takes to Sort it Out!!

34343.description:
An expansion kit for Advanced Squad Leader. But, this is not a historical module. It covers a horror story filled with zombies.

The booklet covers the chapter Z "zobies" which describes the rules for zombies and also for human units who fight the zombies. The zombies are represented by Japanese units. Human units are represented by other country units, National Guard for British units, Law Enforcement for German units, Armed Civilians for American units. The chapter also covers strategy and tactics of these special situations.

6 scenarios are included.

The Orkin Men
Dinner's Waiting
Killing Fields
Hell adn High Water
Women & Children Last
Matchstick Men of the Fighting O

Expands

Advanced Squad Leader
34343.name: Zombie Pak 1

34344.name: Guiearth Saga
34344.description:
This game is attached with Tactics magazine #66 in Japan. This game is fantasy multi-player game covering the era of reconstruction after the long and chaotic war against dragons.
This is the first of Okamoto's triology. The second is Victory in the Galaxy covering sci-fi and the third is Shadow of K's Birlcess covering horror.
These 3 games are real gem which is truely original at the date. Unfortunately even in Japan these games are almost forgotten, because these games were attached with not the boardgame issue but with the RPG issue of Tactics magazine. So that, most Japanese board gamers had no chance to see these games.

34345.description:
This game works like Tic-Tac-Toe combined with playing pieces that look like checkers, but move like a king in chess. It is played on a 4x4 grid, with each player setting up their pieces in a row on opposite sides. On each turn, a player moves their piece one space orthogonally or diagonally. The object is to get 4 in a row orthogonally or diagonally on any row other than your starting row OR to get all your pieces placed in each corner.

The game has some really attractive bakelight pieces.
34345.name: Pentana

34346.name: PowerLunch!
34346.description:
All those business cards that people hand you can finally be put to good use! PowerLunch(tm) is a two-person game where these cards can be used to battle each other for the one thing they are best suited to attain: a free lunch.

Each player draws 5 business cards from a pool of at least 20. Cards are then flicked across the play area and if they land near an opponent's card, they attack using the digits of the main phone number on the card.

Cards are classified as one of three types:
1. Free Agents: Someone who is self employed or freelance (or don't specify their employment). These get two moves per turn.
2. Chiefs: Any card from an executive or someone in an obvious leadership position. These get +1 to attacks if they touch their opponent.
3. Underlings: Anyone else. These may be attached to a Chief, and then moved (by hand) to the Chief's new position after he/she is flicked.

34347.name: Golden Eagle Anagrams
34347.description: This old McLoughlin game features an eagle on the cover holding a large medallion. The contents are basically cardboard scrabble tiles (minus the numbers), used to work out anagrams.

34348.name: Ironrod: The Search for the Tree of Life
34348.description:
Ironrod: The Search for the Tree of Life is an LDS game based on Lehi's vision of the tree of life in 1 Nephi 8 (from the Book of Mormon). The board features a weaving path that goes through the Iron Rod, the Mists of Darkness, the Great and Spacious Building, and the River of Filthy Water. Players draw colored cards that determine what square s/he will go to next. Some special cards allow you to skip ahead, go to a certain part of the board, or force you to go backwards on the path. The winner is the first player to reach the tree of life.

From the publisher: Around 600 BC there lived a prophet named Lehi. Lehi dreamed about a straight and narrow path that led to the Tree of Life. In the center of the path was the Ironrod. By clinging to the Ironrod and pressing forward, one could reach the Tree of Life. Along the path, one must be very careful not to slip away and get trapped in the Mist of Darkness, the River of Water, or the Great and Spacious Building. The consequence for slipping away would cause a prolonged arrival to the Tree of Life. In order to win the game, one must reach Lehi and the Tree of Life by taking the shortest path. The surest way to reach the Tree of Life first is to stay on the path and follow the Ironrod.

34349.name: Niagara
34349.description:
Niagara is a wargame designed to be played on its own or as a vehicle for minitatures campaigns.

Players maneuver an the strategic map using the front sides of the counters.

When a battle is to be fought, a tactical map and the back side of the counters are used.

As a miniatures game, units are moved on a map the same as above. Battles may be resolved using miniatures rules or, if the forces are too small, too unbalanced, or in some other way inappropriate, the battle can be resolved using the "quick combat" method included in the game.

The game is set during the War of 1812 between Canada and the US.

34350.name: All-Time Hockey
34350.description: A tactical hockey simulation featuring some of the best teams in the history of the NHL - the 1967 Toronto Maple Leafs, the 1976 Montreal Canadiens, the 1985 Edmonton Oilers, and the 1989 Calgary Flames.

34352.name: Sturt's Stony Desert
34352.description:
The flip side of the tiles from the game Down Under. This is a simple connection game for 2 players only (though the rules say 2 to 4).

Try to connect your two sides of the board using the tiles with various curved paths on them.

The game has two phases. In the first phase, players take turns laying tiles with just two curves on them. These are either Y shaped forks, or two bends around opposite corners. If you let your opponent complete their path in this phase, you're doing very badly.

In the second phase, players start over-laying the 2 curve tiles with 3 curve tiles. This makes it much easier to complete a path. When one player does so, the other still has a chance to lay a 3 curve to disrupt the path. But 3 curves only go onto 2 curves. So by clever placement, you can force yourself into a path with two solutions, so your opponent cannot block both at once.

It's a remarkably simple design, but seems wide open with possible techniques. Tiles can always be placed in any orientation. The clever part is that a valid path cannot follow an oblique turn. You go round bends like a train on tracks. So by placing a fork in the correct way, I can improve my path but block yours. But when you get to lay 3 curves, you can undo the damage.

34353.name: Spanish Fury, Battle! or Pistolado!
34353.description:
A supplement to the Spanish Fury miniatures gaming rules:

Field Battle rules for the Wars of Religion, 1560-1603. The rules are intended to cover the Wars of Religion in Europe on a regiment scale. The figure scale is 1:40 and ground scale is 1 inch = 25 yards.

34354.description:
From the publisher:

The Spanish Fury system now has modules for Sieges, Field Battles, and Naval Engagements. The Campaign system is just around the corner. One more element was needed to finish the project, and that’s Actions! These rules cover conflicts involving at most 2500 men, at the least about 300. All types of low-level fighting are covered; minor battles, ambushes, raids, prison-breaks, cattle rustling and the storming of forts!

The basic unit of the game is the squadron, which is composed of somewhere between 25-50 men. These are often the size of weak companies, but we use the term company to cover the next administrative level, composed of several squadrons, somewhere between 150-250 men. Each company has a Captain, who has great influence on his men. The overall commander of a side is called a Colonel.

We’ve tried to portray just about every troop type in Europe in these rules, from Irish Kern to Spanish Musketeers. One of our favorite elements of this game is its expandability and "accessable chrome". Anyone can add their favorite forgotten troop type, from Cimaroon to Lap scouts riding Reindeer!
34354.name: Spanish Fury, Actions!

34355.name: Air Combat Maneuver
34355.description: A miniatures air combat game which requires a fairly good sized hex map, a couple of 10-sided dice and several 1/285 scale miniature aircraft on sticks. The game included statistics for World War I and World War II aircraft.

34356.name: Cabo da Roca
34356.description:
Cabo da Roca is situated on the very West tip of Portugal. The lighthouse on Cabo da Roca warns ships following one of the busiest sea routes in the world up to a distance of 100 kilometers. Now, you will put yourself afloat on these sea routes heading towards new adventure.

The game has a Carcassonne-style tile-laying mechanic in which players construct a seascape and port locations turn by turn. As ports appear, players can start buying ships to sail around the sea and trade goods from one town to another. Different types of ships are available, with a pirate ship naturally being one of them, and players try to accumulate the most gold possible through trade and settlement.

34357.name: Over There
34357.description: From a description from the game box and from APGA. This Milton Bradley Game (#4168) produced in 1950 is a simple World War 1 game. The game comes with 10 counters (5 of each color) and 1 dial. The game board features 5 lines of dots 26 dots to the line. The object of the game is to capture your opponent's men. Your moves are governed by numbers indicated by the arrow on the dial which you spin in order to get results. Landing in a "shell hole" (one on each line) makes you safe from capture. In order to capture an opposing piece you must roll and land by exact count on that opponet's piece. Capturing a piece closes the line that that piece was on. Captured pieces can be placed on any other still open line therefore giving you two pieces to use while trying to land by exact count on an opposing piece. First player to capture all of the opposing pieces wins the game.

34358.name: Feast of Warring States Period
34358.description:
'Feast of Warring States Period' is a battle class game of "Battle of Sekigahara(Keityo5/A.D.1600)" that
might be the most famous fight in the history of Japan.

The game includes 1Map(4 A3 size),460 uncut counters.

20 turn all,It corresponds 1 turn : at 25 minutes.
1 hex : 150 - 200m

The Feast of Warring States Period is dipicted with a different system with the current civil wars battle class game.

The correction to the combat value changes by length of the fire range of the combat unit. The morale rule　plays an important role in the attack and the defense.The Command Power Movement rule reproduces the variable of the movement.

"Betrayal" is an important element of Sekigahara.In this game, victory or defeat is not decided by "Betrayal" check once.In a word, the victory condition is changed depending on the number colored to the ally and the number of turns.

34359.name: Supergrips
34359.description:
Game based upon the game show "Supergrips".

You have a wall of combs with opposite sides of the same color.

You have to stick lettersticks behind the combwall and then answer questions relating to the different letters that show up. For each question to one letter that you answer right, you can stick one of your tiles into the wall.

The first player (or team) that can build a continous line between the opposing sides, wins.

34360.name: 1838TL
34360.description:
1838TL (1838: The Thuringia Link) is an 18xx game set in central Germany. This game takes the basic mechanics from 1830, and adds several new elements.

Unique features include the absence of private companies and an effectively unlimited amount of money, because the game ends only when a company's share price reaches 516.
The (weird) map is color-coded because companies are only allowed to build in their historical region.

Overview by Chris Lawson:
Location: Central Germany
Corporations: 13
Privates: none
Map Size: 377 hexes (387 total)
Off-Board: Three steps (2 / 3-4 / 5)
Bank: 21520 Thaler
Tile Colours: Yellow / Green / Brown
Stock Market: 2D (Square)

34361.name: El desafío de la Historia
34361.description:
[EN]
This is an standard trivia game... Roll, move and, depending on the area you are, answer a History question.

There are 6 different categories for the question cards: Ancient History, People, Medieval History, Arts & Literature, Modern & Contemporary History and Curiosities.

It was published & distributed by Spanish History magazine "Historia y vida" in 1998.

[ES]
Es un juego tipo trivia estándar. Tiras el dado, mueves y, dependiendo de la casilla en que estés, respondes a una pregunta de historia.

Hay 6 categorías diferentes para las tarjetas de preguntas: Historia Antigua, Personajes, Historia Medieval, Arte y Literatura, Historia Moderna y Contemporánea y Curiosidades.

El juego fue publicado y distribuido por la revista española de historia "Historia y Vida" en 1998.

34362.description:
From the One Page Wars game series.

The players compete to be the first to earn 100 credits by purchasing buses, trains, and planes and using them to transport passengers for hire between the seven cities on the hex grid mapboard.

Each type of transport unit is rated for cost, movement and passenger capacity. There are a limited number of such units available: 10 aircraft, 5 buses, and 3 trains.

In addition, the players can build a portion of the transportation system, as there are no train tracks marked on the board - the tracks may be purchased and placed by the players during the course of the game.
34362.name: And the Transport Empire

34363.description:
From the One Page Wars game series.

Take the part of a local fire commander and allocate your limited resources to attempt to halt and extinguish a fire sweeping through the valley. You have at your disposal three firefighter units, a fire jumper unit, and a fire suppression aircraft. You may also use "backburn" units to halt the spread of the fire. If you lose any of your firefighters before the entire fire is extinguished, the game is a loss.
34363.name: Fire Storm in Adlore Valley

34364.description:
From the One Page Wars game series.

"The Dutch and Russian Embassies recently opened up in the lovely new nation of Ha Van Teghi. Mr. Von Watley and Mr. Boris as the respective ambassadors."

"Your goal is to take on one of the peronas and attempt to gain the most influence within the new colony as possible before the end of the year."

Players take turns placing their 12 cubes on the board, seeking to establish positions that will garner the most victory points at the end of the game. The players can also seek to invoke the benefits of King Maki-Maki's assistance.
34364.name: Island Embassy

34365.name: B-B Ball Players Baseball Game
34365.description:
This is a dice game, with a baseball theme, from the 1950s, which uses two special dice.

From the card that comes with the game:
"B-B Ball Players Baseball Game - Everything Real but the Umpire. 9 innings - 9 minutes. Anywhere. Anytime. 2 to 18 players. Nu-process Parlor Dice Game."

The rules are stated in a few lines:
"Same as baseball.
Batters cast dice in turn until a play is made.
A pair (2 of a kind) is a play.
No pair is a strike.
Double play when 3 OUTS are shown."

34367.description: Penguins move from ice floe to ice floe. Clever usage of the rolled numbers moves little ice floes which make the course for the 12 penguins - a player moves either his floes or his penguins with one die - the penguins try to reach the large ice floe - but their small ice floes can be robbed by the other players, when a six is rolled.
34367.name: Pingi

34368.name: A Few Bricks Short of a Load
34368.description:
From the game box:
The Exciting Game of Visual Identification!
In this fun and exciting party game, players have 3 minutes to identify the objects pictured on the card.

Category topics range from dog & cat breeds, to candy, sports, cars, flowers, birds, animals and much more! There are categories for almost every interest - so everyone can enjoy the fun!

Players write down their answers and score points for each corrected guess. Every time a player obtains 50 points - they get a brick. The player who builds the tallest tower of bricks at the end of the game wins!

With "loads" of interesting objects and images to guess, A Few Bricks Short of a Load will provide hours of social fun and family entertainment!

Need Some Help? Are you a few bricks short of a load?
Use the "Magic Wand" to reveal the answers - but in a "scrambled order". Be careful as to when you get these answer clues as they will cost you half your points!

34369.name: Bugs Bunny's Hideout game
34369.description:
Bugs Bunny's Hideout Game. Keep Bugs from his hideout and win!

The object of the game is for Bugs Bunny to race to one of his underground carrot hideouts without being caught. The remaining players play the role of Elmer Fud and try to capture Bugs before get gets to one of 5 hideouts, which is kept secret by Bugs Bunny throughout the game. Players spin the wheel and move to one of four colors or “pick a card” which could loose players there turn or move them ahead or back one or two spaces.

If Bugs Bunny makes it to his hideout he wins. If Elmer Fud catches bugs before getting to his hideout then Elmer Fud wins.

34370.name: Very Civile Actions!
34370.description:
A variant of The Perfect Captain's Spanish Fury, Actions! game system of warfare in 16th century Europe, adapted for recreating battles of the English Civil War, 1639-1651.

The variant adds units for the Parliamentarians, Royalists, and Scots. Also added, and common to both armies, are seasoned troops, trained bands, dragoons, firelocks, and clubmen.

34371.name: 9 Treasures
34371.description: "Who gets the best cards gets the best treasures... The treasure seekers try to receive as many matching cards as possible to have valuable treasure-maps!"

34372.name: Sakkara
34372.description:
"A strategic adventure game. You have to reach the center of the pyramid 3 times - for this adventure you have 3 different pieces with different features. On your way you find bridges helping you to get closer to your aim, because only over a bridge you get to the next level. Each time you reach the center, the gods give you more power. But be careful: the other players can send you back to the entrance, take away bridges to another place or reach the Ankh before you..."

Components: gameboard, 12 pieces in 4 colors, 4 Horus cards, 4 ankh cards, 7 bridges.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/sakkara.htm

boardgamehonor: 2008 Mensa Select Winner
2009 Golden Geek Best Children's Board Game Nominee
34373.description:
From the manufacturer:

Welcome to Tiki Island, home to nine colorful carvings all competing to be the top Polynesian Idol! In this fast-paced strategy game, try to maneuver your secret tikis to the top of the line by playing the right combination of action cards. Use a Tiki Up card to move a tiki ahead in line. Tiki Topple sends opponents' tikis tumbling to the back of the pack. But watch out for the sneaky Tiki Toast cards, which knock your tikis off the board! Score the most points and call yourself the Tiki Master.

Part of the Schmidt Spiele Easy Play line.

Ages 10 and up
34373.name: Tiki Topple
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGTG 110 - All About the Easy Play games (with David Arnott)
Podcast EP12 – Événements ludiques
Tiki Topple

34374.description:
From the manufacturer:

Fetch a wave with champion surf dogs Kelly Slobber, Riptail, and Jeff Spicollie in this totally bone-dacious card game. Get the most dogs on surfboards by cashing in sand dollars to retrieve cards. Roll over to the Dog Shack for a chance at collaring another player’s cards. But watch out, greedy gulls may snatch your cash or a monster wave might cause a major wipe out! The player with the most complete surfboards is the top dog.

For ages 8 and up.
34374.name: Hang Four

boardgamehonor: 2009 Games Magazine Best New Party Game Winner
2009 Golden Geek Best Children's Board Game Nominee
2010 Boardgames Australia Awards Best Children's Game Nominee
34375.description:
In Go Nuts!, players want to pile up the acorn points as quickly as they can. On a turn, the active player takes five squirrel dice and rolls them. Any dice showing cars are set aside out of play, while any acorns are worth one point. After each roll, the player can decide to stop and bank the acorn points or roll again.

If they ever roll only squirrels on the dice, they lose any points accumulated that turn and must call out "Go nuts!", now rolling all five dice as quickly as possible and calling out the total number of acorns rolled as they go. All other players are simultaneously rolling one dog die each, which shows a doghouse on five sides and a dog on one. As soon as an opponent rolls a dog, that player barks; once all the opponents have barked, the active player stops rolling and scores all acorns rolled in this special "go nuts" round.

Players take turns until someone scores fifty or more points, thereby winning the game!
34375.name: Go Nuts!
boardgamepodcastepisode: OBG 79: To the Table Top

34376.name: Captain Clueless: Lost in the Caribbean
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode #43 - Captain Clueless and Doodle Quest
34376.description:
From the manufacturer:

Set a course for high seas hilarity aboard this party game that puts you behind the rose-colored sunglasses of Captain R. U. Clueless – the world’s most oblivious cruise ship captain. While blindfolded, try to navigate a clear route to your chosen Caribbean port without running into land or running out of time. Your teammates can help guide you but with only a limited number of clues! The first team to reach their final destination wins. Bon Voyage!

boardgamehonor: 2009 Boardgames Australia Awards Best Children's Game Nominee
34377.description:
From the manufacturer:

Old King Toad is a hungry old soul! In this tongue-twisting card game, add bugs to the king's feast by playing cards in numerical order. If you don't have the next card in sequence, catch one just like King Toad! Say "Ribbit" and then stick out your tongue from one to four times to signal the card you want played. The first player out of cards gets to be King Toad for a day!

For ages 5 and up. Comes with 60 cards and 12 tokens. Rules are in English and Spanish.
34377.name: King Toad

34378.description:
From the manufacturer:

Who is to be the new king of the savannah will be decided by this fierce searching game for 2-4 players. In order to reach the lion temple first the players have to be very observant and quickly spot the animal cards which match the dice.

For ages 5 and up.
34378.name: Löwenstark!

boardgamehonor: 2008 Kinderspielexperten "5-to-9-year-olds" Nominee
34379.description:
From the manufacturer:

Treasures ahoy! Once more Capt’n Look has discovered treasure! His pirates come rushing toward the rail and through their long glasses spot gold, jewels and rum. They have to memorize carefully what they see so that the booty will become theirs. A treasure hunt for 2-4 sharp-eyed pirates.

For ages 5 and up.
34379.name: Käpt'n Kuck

34380.description:
From the manufacturer:

Quack, quack! Charly is amazed by all the animals in the zoo. However, through the peepholes of the enclosures Charly can only see parts of the animals. Who will help Charly recognize them correctly? A memory game demanding close observation for 2-5 players.

For ages 4 and up.
34380.name: Charly at the Zoo

34381.description:
From the manufacturer:

Max Mouse is looking for cheese. But beware! If cat Camilla comes round the corner all the cheese will be gone. A cat-and-mouse game for 2 to 4 cheese collectors.

For ages 5 and up.
34381.name: Käseklau!

34382.description:
From the manufacturer:

Oh dear, Hob Hotchpotch has jumbled up the letters! The eager dwarves try to untangle the chaos. Will they find objects, animals or other motifs starting with the letter searched for? An educational game for 2-4 players all about the alphabet.

For ages 6 to 10.
34382.name: Buchstabenzwerge

34383.description:
From the manufacturer:

Where is Ragged Rat hiding? The mice cops need a fair amount of tracking instincts in order to retrieve the scamp. A rascally rodent searching game for 2-5 players.

Ages 4 and up.
34383.name: Kalle Kanalratte

34384.name: Traffic Patterns
34384.description:
A 2-4 player game of changing lanes, high-speed turns, and flipping people off.

Game Summary:
Players move their car from row 1 to row 15, avoiding traffic and influencing other cars to get in the way of their opponents.

Components:
A bunch of toy cars (ten or more works well), of roughly the same size.
A six sided die for each player.
One sheet of scrap paper for each player.

Everything needed to play is available in the BGG files section, or at:
Games by Jeremiah

34385.name: Black Fire
34385.description:
This expansion adds magic-user characters, and allows games with up to 10 players.

Expands:

Blood Master.

34386.name: Auf zur Burg
34386.description:
Game about exploration of Burghausen, a little city in the south of Bavaria in Germany.

Each player retrieves two cards from each of three parts of the city to which he has to go. Travelling is done by rolling the dice. If a player reaches one of his targets he has to read the text of the card and follow its instructions that usually favour far away locations and add handicaps to near locations.

Beside the normal movement there exist two special movements: one clockwise around the map by travelling by bus and one counter clockwise by travelling by 'Plätte' (tourist ships that were used for shipping salt along the river in former times.) The special movements normally increase your travel speed but add the risc of too far movements.

After a player has reached all his targets he has to move to the castle of Burghausen (the longest in Europe or probably in the world) in the middle of the game map. There he has to roll the dice for each of the six castle wards. The first player to reach the most inner ward wins the game.

34387.name: Guzzlin' Gators
34387.description: This game very closely resembles Hungry Hungry Hippos, except the hippos are replaced by alligators and the lever mechanism that causes the heads to eat the marbles operates a bit differently, requiring more pushing than pulling. The game includes twenty plastic marbles for the gators to eat along with a rule sheet providing multiple variations on play.

34388.name: Straights
34388.description:
The players try to get 100 points by playing Straights.

A Straight can be open (vulnerable to special cards but more valuable) or closed (immune to specials cards but only worth the half of an open Straight).

Cards can be used to building Straight or for special actions (there is reminder text on the cards). There is a lot of interaction between the players because you have a lot of possibilities to mess with the other players and their Straights.

Components
2-4 Players need 2 Sets of Cards (110 cards) and every player needs a die as action buffer.

If you want to play with more than 4 players you need additional sets of cards.

34389.name: The Heights
34389.description:
This is a 3-D pyramid game where you move pieces up and down the pyramid. It actually ships with three games in the rules that utilize the common movement mechanism of moving around the pyramid (and/or jumping like checkers).

Kaptor - capture all of your opponents pieces

The Crown - have 5 of your pieces fill the top five holes at the top of the pyramid

The Voyage - fill the six bottom slots on the opposite side of the board where your opponent started

34390.name: Bakugan Battle Brawlers
34390.description:
A hybrid of CCG, Marbles and Transforming Robots, this dexterity game represents a battlefield, with competing forces battling for control.

Each player takes turns shooting the marble-like Bakugan at the metal cards which have been placed to make up the play area. If the Bakugan lands at the right spot on the card, it will spring open and stand on the card, taking control of the card. When two Bakugan stand on the same card, they fight, using their strength, plus bonuses on the card they are attempting to control. Play continues until all areas are controlled, or one player's Bakugan have been eliminated. The winner is determined by the values of the areas taken, and other bonuses accumulated in play.

34391.name: Isabelle & Isabeau
34391.description:
Isabelle & Isabeau takes us back to the Mediaeval days when knights were bold and princesses charming! Bit like "families", but the dice make the difference.

Basic Rules:

In this game, you try to win as if you were playing a game of "pure" families - indeed you need to build two families of six similar cards to win. But the dice make things interesting.

There are 3 of them: the first is a Character die that denotes either you or one of your opponents, and the other two are Action dice. Typical actions are: draw a card, place a card, discard a card, steal a card from an opponent, swap hands with an opponent, roll again etc etc.

When it is your turn you roll the dice. You will perform one of the actions on the Action dice, knowing that the other one must be carried out by the person shown on the Character die. You choose who is going to do what, and in what order.

Isabelle & Isabeau game doesn't require any grand strategies, but the game mechanism conjures up some interesting combinations.
You may discard most of your hand only to swap it immediately with another player. You may may need to choose between the lesser of two evils yourself. Memory plays an important role: knowing who has which cards in their hand can be vital. And jokers and "veto" cards add some extra twists and turns.

In short, this is a quick, fun game with lots of "mediaeval" illustrations. Oh, and did you get the pun in the title? No? Time to brush up on your French grammar, then...
Isabelle and Isabeau has just been released in mainland Europe, and will be available shortly in the UK. See www.isimat.fr for details or contact muellbauer@lycos.com

34392.name: Dr. Arnvie's Grand Rounds
34392.description:
Dr. Arnvie's[tm] Grand Rounds[tm] is a medical-themed trivia game produced by The Vincent Company, Inc. [Gledale, WI].

While the game follows the basic "Trivial Pursuit" approach to game play, every element is based on a medical theme. Even the rule sheet is presented as a "Prescription Form," which notes Refill: PRN (As needed for fun).

Per the rules: "Each player acts as a resident physician. (A resident physician is a doctor who is undergoing specialty training following medical school.)

At the start of the game, each player is given 10 patient cards [which] represent the patients that the player must try to discharge during the course of the game. One patient is discharged each time a question is answered correctly."

The first player to discharge all his/her patients wins.

As per the Trivial Pursuit model, there are color-coded spaces on the board that correspond to question categories. The 4 categories are:
Green-History and Personalities
Yellow-General Medicine
Red-Anatomy & Surgery; Public Health; Preventative Medicine
Blue-Nutrition & Exercise.

In addition, other spaces offer exceptions to the color code system and present players with alternative Bonus and Risk cards that can modify their position on the board or choice of question categories.

The rules conclude with a directive [keeping with the prescription pad theme] for "NO GENERIC SUBSTITUTIONS" and "Keep within reach of inquisitive teenagers & adults."

This is followed with a fairly substantial disclaimer that though this game is based on reputable sources, one should turn to Dr. Arnvie for advice on medical treatment or conditions but should, instead, consult your regular medical provider.

34393.name: Danger City
34393.description:
Danger City is a speedy card game where you can win in one of two ways: you can side with the Neighbourhood, or with the Robbers. Either have the fewest robbers in your hand and the most points on the table once the final house has been built – or reveal 5 Robbers at once from your hand, and you have won.

Danger City takes its inspiration from so-called “Gated Communities” that one may find in plush suburbs of North American (or English?) cities, and the idea that you must either be a very paranoid person to live in one, or have very good reason to want to protect yourself from someone!

We are taken to an idyllic neighbourhood that is in full-blown development – houses are being built, as well as parks, amenities, services and the like.
But somewhere things go wrong: a gang of robbers have arrived. The neighbourhood takes decisive action and starts to install surveillance systems, to thwart their enemies. But who will win out?

Basic Rules

Players take turns in building the neighbourhood, by playing Neighbourhood cards from their hand onto the table. Each card has a specific value – a Garage is worth 5 points while a Golf Course is worth 15. Cards circulate round the player from player to player: you draw or play a card and then pass one on face down. Lurking in their midst are a rabble of robbers. Chances are you either want to collect them or get rid of them, but you cannot play them like Neighbourhood cards. If you collect 5 of them, you can reveal them all at once from your hand and win. You have “sided with the robbers!”

Otherwise the game ends when a specific number of House cards have been played – twice the number of players. At that point the game stops and the player with the FEWEST robbers in their hand wins. If there is a tie, then Neighbourhood points come into play – whoever has played down the most points wins.

And that’s pretty much it!

Strategy

Essentially the game has been designed so that it is equally likely that the game will be won after the final House card has been played, or via the Robbers. You are as likely to draw House cards as you are Robbers, so either route is viable.

The game hots up as the final few Houses are being built – no-one wants to be left with a bunch of robbers after the last House card is played, or indeed if you are collecting robbers, you need to make damn sure that you manage to get five of them before the last House Card gets played. So as the game draws to its end, players are frantically trying to lose robbers…or collect robbers…or indeed play Neighbourhood cards. But the skillful player will realise that it’s not just the final sprint that counts.

Obviously you know what card you are receiving from the player on the right and which card you are feeding to the player on the left, so chances are you have a fair idea of where robbers might be amongst your competitors – and working out who is trying to do what is key. E.g. If you have been receiving a glut of Robbers that suddenly dries up – that should tell you something. You can also win by playing the turncoat, or looking like you are doing one thing while secretly doing another.

The game is currently only available in mainland Europe, but is set to become available imminently in the UK, retailing at around £7.
See www.isimat.fr or email muellbauer@lycos.com for details

34394.name: España en llamas
34394.description:
"España en llamas" is a special issue of Spanish magazine "Wargames, soldados y estrategia", which also has an English language version called, of course, "Wargames, Soldiers and Strategy".
The magazine has 138 pages and it adapts the Spanish Civil War to the "Flames of War" miniatures rules system.
The first pages are a historical introduction to the conflict,while the rest has several army lists, scenarios and missions for the game.
The magazine also includes an extra boardgame about the Spanish Civil War too, "El eco de los pasos" (see entry).

34395.description:
Educational, family-friendly trivia game based on the BBC's blockbuster five-part documentary, Planet Earth. Question topics range from wildlife, geology and earth science, and geology to the environment, biology, and weather.

In the Imagination Games version, players answer the questions cooperatively in attempt to win prizes. The prizes are puzzle pieces, which are supposed to represent important clues that are key to solving global warming, deforestation, overpopulation, and other grave challenges threatening the planet.

The Alga version is competitive, and players answer questions secretly using chits. The question category is chosen using a spinner and there are no puzzle pieces - player points are simply recorded on the board using pawns.

Ages 8 and up.
34395.name: Planet Earth DVD Game
videogamebg: Planet Earth the Interactive DVD Game

34396.name: La Battaglia di Waterloo
34396.description:
Game for two players of the battle of waterloo for children. Map divided in squares, simple rules, counters type miniatures and the combats are solved of way similar to checkers.
Components: book of rules,book history,map and miniatures paper.

34397.name: Perykles
34397.description:
Perykles is a game about Greek ancient wars against Persian. It comprises a full colour map, counters need to be cut. The rules are in Polish.

Game is based on same system that as Hannibal Ante Portas

Game has 2 main elements
- There is strategical map of ancient Greece and parts of Asia minor, where players control countries, and provinces, gather taxes and recruit armies. Each territory produces up to fixed amounts of recruitment potential measured in men. Regions differ both in potential numbers and kinds of units that are recruitable.
Units are simple graded - Light/ Heavy infantry, light/ heavy cavalry.

Map movement is by army counters.
When an army crosses neutral province system of friendliness let players decide possible outcome from war, through neutrality to joining trespasser as ally.
There are rules for sieges, forced marches and pillaging.

-When 2 armies meet, Game is using metagame to play a battle.
Battle board has 12 fields
each players Right-flank , centre and right flank, and respective second lines.
Players place their forces in secret and give each part of the field an secret order such as Attack or Defense.

Game features historical scenarios, but is quite open.

34398.name: Auctioneer
34398.description:
Auctioneer is a game in which the players take the place of dealers and collectors from overseas, who by buying and selling aim to build up a collection of antiques and objects d'art. The winner of the game is the player who by shrewd dealing, has aquired all the available property and money, thus eliminating his opponents.

Each of the 48 articles illustrated in the game is a genuine work of art and all of them may be seen at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London

34399.name: World War I
34399.description:
WORLD WAR I
ww.educationalcards.net
ULES (for 3 or 4 players)
AIM: To collect and arrange six Nation-related card events in chronological order.
Each player represents a Nation and must collect cards whose events are relevant
to their Nation. The timeline must contain the following suits:
One "Pre-War Event" card (Purple cards) - Four "War Event" cards (Orange cards) -
One "Post-War Event" card (Green cards).
Each single card displays the points per Nation. These can be zero to three, where
zero indicates that the event is not very relevant to that Nation and three indicates
that the event is very relevant or decisive. Points are found below the original flags.
Dates are found below the card title. These are usually "month-year" (e.g. March 1915)
but some dates are more 'flexible' and embrace a larger period of time (e.g. April-May 1915,
1915-1917, etc.). All cards contain a "Fact" information.
These rules refer to a full round (game). If time allows, more rounds can be played
and a tournament could be set up. Points are collected at the end of each round

34400.name: Singing Bee Game
34400.description:
A CD-and-board game for ages 8 and up. Sing along with the CD and travel the board, trying to be the first player to make it to the stage for the showdown.

Based on the short-lived NBC version of the game show, hosted by Joey Fatone (seen on the cover).

34401.name: Owzthat! Cricket: The Classic Cricket Game.
34401.description:
Roll the classic " Owzthat " dice to bat. Roll for runs and answer questions to score. More runs mean harder questions.
Roll an " Owzthat " and your opponent has the chance to get you out. Keep tally on the score board provided.
This game has all the fun and excitement of the classic " Owzthat " game with the added ingredient of questions.

34402.name: Melthoen
34402.description: Melthoen is a game with medieval battle system. It comprises a brown-black-white map, counters need to be cut. The rules are in Polish.

34403.description:
Philip Sabin is a Professor of Strategic Studies at King's College in London. One of the tools that he uses for exploring ancient battles is simulation.

In this 298 page book, Sabin guides us through the creation of a system for simulating pitched battles in the ancient period, and then applies the system to 35 historical battles. Scenario setups are shown on color plates.

The rules for the system are approximately 16 pages long, and can be used with either miniatures or counters. (Counters are available for free download from the author's Web site.) Armies have roughly 20 units, which are graded into Veteran, Average, and Levy training levels. Battlefields are divided into a rectangular grid 5 areas wide by 4 areas deep. Each turn, players throw a single die to determine command points, which allows units to move and fight between areas. Veteran units require few points to command. Unit states are very simple: fresh, spent, and shattered (eliminated).

The book contains extensive references to both primary and secondary sources.

Fifth Column Games version is found at Lost Battles.
34403.name: Lost Battles:  Reconstructing the Great Clashes of the Ancient World
boardgamepodcastepisode: Serious Games At Work, episode 6: Philip Sabin

34404.name: Metropoly
34404.description:
For ages 13 and up. Contents: one gameboard, 55 shop cards, 14 owner cards, 26 instruction cards, 6 tokens, 18 counters, 2 dice and fake money.
This game has mechanics similar to classic Monopoly, but it offers more options and a different gameboard.

34405.name: Tinker Fox
34405.description:
A miniatures rules system designed to recreate garrison warfare in the English Midlands during the English Civil War.

"What we wanted to do in Tinker Fox was to drop you into the boots of a Governor of a district in the English Civil War. A Governor does more than fight battles. He must first and foremost follow his masters’ orders. They are usually vague, and it is up to him to come up with a plan to implement them. He must then try to get his subordinates to carry out his detailed instructions. Unfortunately they often have their own agendas and personalities that he must deal with. He must also run an extensive civil government, which is not directly simulated, but is represented by delays and obstructions they naturally cause to military matters."

"Tinker Fox will generate numerous and varied types of battles with whatever troops are present in the campaign. These can be replayed using our new Very Civile Actions! cards now available as a variant for Spanish Fury, Actions! Let the games begin!"

The components consist of a rulebook, quick reference data sheet, unit control sheet, mapsheet and a set of counters.

34406.name: Battlefinder!
34406.description:
Battlefinder! is a campaign generation supplement for use with the various miniatures rules released by The Perfect Captain. It is also suitable for use as a campaign generator for other gaming systems set in Western Europe, for the period 1000 to 1700 A.D.

"It is in essence a modular campaign board that can be used in thousands of configurations. You can use this in conjunction with our miniature rules sets (Ironbow, Spanish Fury, Actions! and Spanish Fury, Battle! or Pistolado!) or with any other set you might own (for those of you who dare to touch a non-Perfect Captain product…you know who you are!). This set can be used in a variety of ways, some of which I’m sure you’ll develop yourselves - and if you do develop something, don’t forget to write it up for our Yahoo group, and share it with us all."

"The cards included with this campaign generator can be used to simulate most areas of Western Europe from the Pyrenees to the edge of the Eurasian Steppes, and from the Alps to Scandanavia."

The Battlefinder! components include a rulebook, a mapsheet, terrain cards and a set of counters.

Like all games from The Perfect Captain, Battlefinder is available for free download to print and play. (See Web Links.)

34407.name: Cast for a Bite
34407.description:
Contents

390 Fish Cards
130 Bait Cards
60 Snag Cards
2 Spot Dice
1 Fish Size Dice
Electronic Count Down Timer (Batteries supplied)
6 Coloured Playing Pieces
Board
Rules




From the back of the box:

"Cast for a Bite combines all the anticipation, skill and luck of competitive fishing, allowing players to experience the excitement and sense of achievement when a big fish is caught.

Players travel around the river and lake on the board collecting beautifully illustrated fish and bait cards, whilst keeping an eye on the clock and trying to avoid the snag cards, never knowing if the next catch will help win the game or the next snag will set them back."

34408.name: Viatge per Catalunya
34408.description:
Simple game of competition in which the players must travel around Catalonia visiting certain places determined randomly by cards.
For ages 8 and up. Contents: one mapboard with the map of Catalonia, 87 illustrated visit cards, 6 travel cards, one die and 6 tokens.

34409.name: Larkspur
34409.description: Larkspur is an educational card game which aims to teach children how to identify and name flowers and flower families. It comprises a pack of 60 cards, organized into 12 sets of 5 cards, with the first card in each set depicting a garden flower and the other 4 cards depicting related field flowers. The rulebook contains instructions on how to play three different games with the cards, all of which involve the collection of complete sets of cards via a number of routes.

34410.description:
This 1-tile expansion for Caylus was a free give-away at the Essen 2005 fair.

The tile depicts the "Jeweller" and can be used to trade gold for points in a 1:5 and 2:9 ratio (gold:points)

Later, the tile was made available for download on the Ystari website (download available in the Links section below).

The Jeweller tile is also included with the Premium Limited Edition of Caylus.
boardgameversion: Ystari Premium Limited Edition included edition
34410.name: Caylus Expansion: The Jeweller

34411.name: My Alphabet Card Game
34411.description:
A game for children to help them learn their letters and words. Per the back of the box...

"There are lots of games to play with these colorful alphabet cards. You can play a competitive matching game, where the winner finds the most sets of cards or a cooperative Memory game.

You can also:
*Identify the letters and name the objects in the pictures
*Match the lower and upper case letters
*Put the cards in alphabetical order
*Spell simple words
*There are lots of possibilities!

All the while, children learn the alphabet and build their vocabulary.

Great to take with you wherever you go, the games play quickly, are easy to learn and fun to share!"

34412.description:
Everyone starts at Barbapapas house in the center of the board and gets a card with an animal on it.
The object of the game is to find the Barbapapa figure that has been transformed into the animal on your card, and then return to the house in the center of the board. The nine different Barbapapa figures are placed on the board with the card faces down.
Movement consists of rolling a die and moving. There are spaces on the board that will cause the playing piece to be moved to another space when it is landed upon.
The game is aimed at children, from about 5 years of age. It is very simple, but an easy to learn entry game.
34412.name: Barbapapas kurragömma

34413.description:
From the publisher's website:

AirWar C21 (2nd edition)makes the complex subject of modern air combat so disgustingly simple that it is ideal for beginners and experienced gamers alike. After a couple of games reference to the rule book will become occassional with players concentrating on shooting down their opponents rather than ploughing through the sub-minutiae of clauses and appendices.

Includes:
Rules for aircraft characteristics movement, special manoeuvres, dog fighting and air-to-air missiles.
Optional rules for ground attack, surface-to-air fire, spotting, ejection and crashing.
ratings for 114 modern aircraft from the Chengdu Jianjiji-7A to the F-35B JSF, plus 92 AAM's, 59 SAM's, 5 gunpods, 72 anti-ground weapons and 26 AAA weapons.

A re-implemintation of AirWar: C21 Lite

Expanded by


AirWar: C21 Data Annex
AirWar: C21 Max Edition
34413.name: AirWar: C21 (2nd Edition)

34414.description:
From the publisher's website:

The AirWar: C21 Data Annex is a downloadable PDF supplement for AirWar: C21 (2nd edition) available exclusively from Wargaming Online. The supplement repalces the statistical tables in the standard rulebook with more aircraft, AAMs, bombs etc.

Includes:
Statistics for 358 aircraft from the IA58 Pucara to F-117A Nighthawk.
Statistics for 112 AAMs, 10 gunpods, 120 AGWs, 81 SAMs and 44 AAA weapons.

Not a stand-alone game, it expands AirWar: C21 (2nd Edition)
34414.name: AirWar: C21 Data Annex

34415.description:
From the publisher's website:

The AirWar: C21 Max edition is a downloadable PDF combining the AirWar: C21 PDF edition rulebook and AirWar: C21 Data Annex available exclusively from WargameVault.com.

Includes:
The AirWar: C21 PDF edition rulebook.
The AirWar: C21 Data Annex supplement replacing the stats in the basic rulebook
34415.name: AirWar: C21 Max Edition

34416.description:
Fifth entry in the English Civil War series, this DTP wargame depicts two different battles, Alford and Auldearn, both victories of the Earl of Montrose, a Royalist general, during his second Scottish campaign.
Each battle has a single A4 full color map and about 40 counters.

Available through Wargamedownloads.com and Arima.it as direct download, and through Boulder Games and Noble Knight Games as printed DTP wargame.
34416.name: Montrose Triumphs

34417.name: Ghoul!
34417.description:
The frightful ghoul is hanging around in Scary Castle. The little ghosts quickly hide! Will the frightful find and frighten them with a loud "Booo"? A wickedly frightening guessing game for 2-5 players.

Further info: Each ghost must choose a room within the castle where they can hide. One player chooses a room card and keeps it hidden from the other players. Who will be frightened when the ghoul shows up in their room? Ages 4+. Included: 1 game board 5 little ghosts 6 room cards 15 eerie tiles 1 set of game instructions - For Age Range:

34418.name: Interventionists
34418.description:
A supplement for the Russian Civil War game Red Actions. It adds a number of "interventionist" units of various nationalities. It also revises a number of components for Red Actions.

Available for free download from:
http://perfectcaptain.50megs.com/request.html

34419.name: Kheops
34419.description:
In Kheops, players are rival architects taking part in the building of the great pyramid. In turn, player place tiles (rooms and corridors) and pawns (workers, priests, mummy, and even pharaoh) on the pyramid building site. Of course, some tiles have special features, like sarcophagi or curses. There are even rumors of rotating corridors and secret networks.


Challenging game for two players! Keep an eye on your opponent. Look where he lays his tiles in the pyramid and where he places his game pieces. Are you able to see through his plans?
Two things to keep in mind! Occupy as many ankh-symbols as possible, but also try to make the largest possible labyrinth in which all other symbols are present.
Very dynamic game! On most of the tiles you lay in the pyramid an action is pictured. They often have a direct effect on the game: tiles are turned over, game pieces are placed or they are of influence on the ending score. So keep paying attention!
Unique wooden playing pieces. The wooden playing pieces are designed especially for this game and also all have a different function in the game. In combination with the sleek design, this game is a feast for the eyes!

34420.name: Republocrat
34420.description:
(From the back of the box) Republocrat is a game which combines a basic knowledge of American History along with luck and skill. Players travel around a circle of spaces named Democracy Boulevard to work towards their ultimate goal: Election to the Presidency. the spaces on the board allow the players to consecutively move into 5 offices prior to reaching the final stage of the game. The final stage of the game finds players at the National Convention and the White House. The offices that players must pass through are: City Council, State Senate, US House of Representitives, Governor of the State and US Senate.

Players may suffer setbacks or gain sudden rewards during the game. Depending if the player answers the question correctly determines if the player moves ahead. In addition, when a player receives a "Republocrat Card", it may require the player to move ahead or go back as indicated on the card.

Republocrat not only entertains, it challenges and informs those seeking election to the presidency. The 240 United States of America questions will allow people to play the game many, many times and enjoy a new experience each time.

34421.name: Big Apple
34421.description:
In this game, players manage stores in New York City. Stores are established in spaces on the apple-shaped board, and players manage their inventory by holding onto cards representing goods. These cards are purchased from warehouse spaces and frequently change hands since a player is obliged to purchase a card whenever he or she lands on an opponent's store. The maximum price which may be charged for an item depends on the number of floors in a store, so players are constantly expanding their outlets.

The game deals with more than just cash -- every player gets a balance sheet used for tracking bank loans and credit with other players. Credit limits are determined at the start of the game and affect the length of the game -- a $300 limit is recommended for an hour-long game, while $500 can last two hours or more. As players reach their credit limits and are unable to pay back their creditors, they go bankrupt and drop out of the game.

In addition to the normal flow of buying and selling, the game features board spaces and cards that spice up gameplay with random events. There are also some special transportation spaces (taxis and subways) which allow players a little more control over their movement to add variety to the normal rolling and moving.

Big Apple obviously draws a lot of inspiration from Monopoly, but it's not just a retheming -- there are enough differences to make it distinct from its more famous predecessor.

34422.name: Gnemo
34422.description: Gnemo is a card game based on (and featuring) the illustration work of artist Tom Kidd. The thematic material for the game is from the imaginary world developed in Kidd's Gnemo series of paintings.

34423.name: Indy's Gamble
34423.description:
From the designer's web site: Indy's Gamble is a brand-new card game featuring Indy and his famous movie adventures. There has not been an Indy game like this one before. The idea and design of the game was developed by me (Sascha Krasny) especially for the Indy style of adventures. The game is made for all Indy fans all over the world, especially for the readers of my page :). And now the best part: The game is completely free.

Available for download at:
http://stud4.tuwien.ac.at/~e9125985/IJC/Games/IndysGamble/

34424.name: Cinquo
34424.description: An abstract strategy game played on a 7x7 grid. The object of the game is to be the first to visit each corner and the center space, ending on the player's starting corner. However, players must play a hand of cards to determine which player gets to move. Players are dealt three cards and have to win a trick to move one of their pieces. The cards are marked like dominoes, with 1 to 6 spots, and each number comes in three different colors - red, black, and white.

34425.name: Economy
34425.description:
"By moving to the right locations you get inventions, factories and shops. With these properties you can collect points and become winner with the most points! A shop is worth 1 point, a factory 2 points and an invention 3 points (most for the invention, because without a new invention there are no new factories and shops!) You get most if you have an invention, factory and shop of the same sector. But be careful - there is keen competition!"

Components: 8x8 game board, 36 location cards, 36 property cards, 6 pieces, die.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/economy.htm

34426.name: High Noon
34426.description:
The object of the game is to eliminate all opposing pieces.

Each player has six movement points to divide among a set of four pieces. Two pieces from each set move clockwise and the other two move counter clockwise.

Pieces landing on the same square duel. In order to win the duel, the player challenged to a duel must correctly guess whether an odd or even number of fingers will be simultaneously held up by both players.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/high.htm

34427.name: Checkpoints
34427.description: The players race across a 6x6 grid seeking to be the first to visit all four corners, with the caveat that a player's starting corner cannot be the first corner visited by the player. The spaces on the board are covered by numbered cards. Dice are rolled for movement. The player can only move onto squares showing the same number as was rolled on a die.

34428.name: K.O.
34428.description:
Each player has a set of pieces numbered 1 through 6. The object is to knock the pieces of your opponents out of the game while keeping your pieces in the game. Two standard dice are rolled for movement. The number rolled indicates both which pieces may be moved (as they are numbered one through six), and the value on the other die indicates the distance of the move. Each piece can only knock out opposing pieces bearing the same number.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/knockout.htm

34429.name: AlphaOmega
34429.description: The game is played on a 10x10 grid having letters of the alphabet marked along the row and column running through the center of the board. The players select a word at the start of the game and seek to visit all of the letters of the word in order. Landing on an opponent's piece sends it back to the start.

34430.name: Right-Left
34430.description:
An abstract strategy game played on a 7x7 grid. Four starting spaces are marked in the four player colors. The object of the game is to visit each of the four colored spaces on the board, ending with the space of your own color. Movement is controlled by a pair of dice, one dictating which direction the piece must turn during the move, and the other setting the distance of the move.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/rile.htm

34431.name: Witches and Wizards
34431.description:
Players take turns laying down cards marked with different animals, seeking to "enchant" a previously played card. The winner of each round is the player who was last able to enchant a card. There are scoring and victory conditions for party games, easy games, and "professional" games. The game consists of 32 animal cards, 2 bacillus cards, and a magic formula card.

http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/witch.htm accessibility

34432.name: State Fair: Ferris Wheel KnockOut
34432.description:
This game is a sort of shooting gallery for at home in a ferris wheel theme. Your target is to shoot sensors with a sort of laser-gun. When you hit the sensor with the laser a balloon pops. This game can be played alone as well as with several players (using time targets for example).

It came in a lot of different variants, all in the State Fair style (see other names). Also a lot of other target shooting games exists nothing to do with those of this brand, but they may be listed here as well.

34433.name: Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone: Levitating Challenge Electronic Skill and Action Game
34433.description:
In this game you have to put a floating ball through a kind of maze, without hitting any objects, so the ball keeps floating. Time is the target of this game when you play it with more then one person.

From the box back:

"How fast can you navigate the ball through this magical maze challenge?"

"Use your powers of levitation to actually raise the ball out of the cauldron...it's amazing! Then, skillfully navigate the ball around the maze as fast as you can in mid-air! Listen to the wizard trainer's instructions as you go - he'll record your time and let you know if you've mastered the art of levitation."

34434.name: Ike-A-Doo Crazy Ikes Game
34434.description:
Object: To assemble, piece by piece, one of the figures on the spinner board. Each figure has twelve parts which are to be chosen by shape and not necessarily by color. First player who completes h is figure and calls, "Ike-A-Doo" is the winner.

Colorful, nostaligic game of putting together legs, heads, arms, feet and torsos into robotic-like figures called, among many others, Cap'n Ike, Ike-A-Roo, Dopey-Ike and Lazy-Ike.

34435.name: Kostky
34435.description: This is a Travel Line (pocket} edition game named Kostky published by Dino Toys in the Czech Republic. It contains six plastic dice, a dice cup, a scoring pad and a booklet of Czech and Slovak rules. Apparently it is a set of rules to play a variety of dice games.

34436.name: Carpet Bowls
34436.description: Carpet Bowls is an indoor version of Lawn Bowls. The players take turns rolling their balls such that one of their balls is the closest to the Jack after all the balls have been rolled. Hitting the other player's balls to move them further from the Jack is allowed, along with hitting the Jack itself. The balls are specially weighted so that they will curve to the right or left depending on how you roll them.

34437.name: Puko
34437.description: A Polish (?) game with cards and chips a bit similar to Tripoley. This is playing without the board and with 1 deck of PUKO-cards. In the box are rules for two others cards games too.

34438.name: Hund und ...?
34438.description:
The content.
36 cards
Each card contains 3 items:
a dog and...
2 displays from the following list:
tree-car-ship-hat-moon-ball-girl-boy

The basic idea of "Hund und...?" is to develop the capability of recognizing differently displayed symbols as similar.

There are two game ideas included. The more challenging one is the second one, where the players have to notice whether any of the other items (besides the dog) appears on two cards in a row. Whoever recognizes this first, gets the cards. This variant is suitable for kids about six and up.

34439.name: Wimbledon
34439.description:
Content:
4 pawns, 4 score markers, 1 ball, 2 dice, 23 tennis cards, 1 board

Both players try to decide the mathch for themselves. The match is decided by skill, dices and tennis cards.

34441.name: Silber Dollar
34441.description:
29 cards with symbols from the wild west, dollar coins, dollar bills
2 Games:
(1) Drunter und Drueber. A Cardgame for 3 or 4 Players.
(2) Texas-Round-Up. For any Number of Players.
First edition with silver coins, second edition with yellow coins.

34442.description:
Summary
An abstract game in which the numbers 1-16 have to be arranged into rows, using five auxiliary columns and careful planning.

Aim of the game
Each player tries to lay three new rows, each of them starting with 1 and ending with 16, with all the numbers in between in their correct sequence. The player who first completes his/her three rows wins the game.

Game play
Each player gets 48 number tiles (three sets of numbers 1-16) and arranges them in three horizontal rows from 1 to 16. One player is selected as the caller, shuffles his/her tiles and draws them one by one from a bag. He/she calls the number drawn. Each player takes that number from one of his/her horizontal rows. If it is a 1, he/she can start one of his/her three new main rows. If it is any other number, it has to be placed in an auxiliary column first.

Each player may have up to 5 vertical auxiliary columns of any length. There must not be any gaps (i.e. tiles must be placed directly below one another), and tiles must not be rearranged later. Tiles need not be placed in sequence, but they should be placed in a way that allows for efficient removal to construct the main rows. Tiles may only be taken from the auxiliary columns starting at the bottom (not in the middle or top), and main rows can only be started when a 1 has been called.

Each of the three new rows has to be started with a 1. The tiles have to be placed in correct sequence here. A 3 can only be placed after a 2, and so on. Tiles can be taken from the auxiliary columns (without being called again) as soon as the number at the bottom directly follows one at the end of one of the player’s main rows. E.g. if there is a 3 at the end of one of the player’s main rows and a 4 at one of his/her auxiliary columns, the 4 may be taken and placed next to the 3 in the main row. Tiles can be taken from the bottom of the auxiliary columns as long as they are in matching sequence.

The player who first completes his/her three rows wins the game. If no player is able to complete all three rows by the time the caller calls the last number, the player with the fewest tiles left wins instead.
34442.name: 3x16

34443.name: The Dictionary Game
34443.description: This has a lot of similarities to Balderdash, but has some differences as well. First is spelling can win you points. Second is it ships with two actual Scribner dictionaries for checking on answers. Finally is how it constrains someone just about to win... There is also a handicap system. So this Canadian publisher seems to have worked out a slightly more sophisticated system to the same fun we know as Balderdash, but added enough additional stuff to make it a bit more strategic in play and more educational to boot.

34444.description:
Misterio is a simplified version of the Clue game with a fantasy/horror theme.

From the box:"Misterio es un juego para detectives de 9 a 99 años, en el que pueden participar de 2 a 6 jugadores. Los hechos se desarrollan en el Castillo de Transilvania cuando un excéntrico aristócrata y la servidumbre que allí vivian, desaparecen en extrañas circunstancias. Los únicos datos que se tienen, están basados en leyendas y supersticiones de las gentes del lugar, sobre los monstruos que en él habitan y que en las noches de luna llena, regresan y atacan a todo aquel que ose vivir allí."

The game is about solving the mysterious disappearances by a process of elimination. The winner will be the detective that manages to solve the 3 keys: "Mis" "Te" "Rio".
34444.name: Misterio

34445.name: Tolle Tanten tanzen Tango
34445.description:
Content:
77 word cards, 33 picture cards

Each player gets 7 word- and picture-cards. Alternating the cards are played separately. The destination is to build a senseful sentence. Are the co-players not content with the word of my choice they had to be convinced. Mostly an incredible sentence construction with fantastic content is getting develloped. The winner is who gets played all cards and ends a sentence with that last card.

34446.name: Wer ist wer?
34446.description:
Content:
1 board,
6 pawns,
2 dice,
6 Wanted pictures,
44 cards,
6 profile cards

The board shows a town with different streets.
There are 6 different wanted-photos of potential offenders.
Each player tries to identify and to arrest a delinquent first to win the game.

34447.name: Happycross
34447.description:
Content:
1 board,
1 Sand glass,
1 dice cup,
13 dice,
1 block

The dice show the different characters of the alphabet with a point score. The rarer a character, the higher the value.
The active player throws 13 dice, and the sand glass starts to run.
Now the player has time to bring the dice into right order at the board so that they lay crossword like at the board.
The sand glass limits the time.

Now the points are counted. Not used characters bring minus points.

34448.name: Kerlett
34448.description:
Content:
1 board, 1 dice cup, 5 dice, 1 block, 36 chips

At the beginning each player gets a set of chips in one color. The dice are thrown. All players play at the same time and try to place their chips a tdifferent places of the board.
You may not place a second one in a field.
